DOC.HEAD: Bush Says Noriega Asylum Request Ends `Reign of Terror'
Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 11th graf pvs bgng, `The Italian,' to UPDATE with comment from Noriega's lawyer
DOC.TEXT: President Bush welcomed news that Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega had sought asylum at the Vatican mission in Panama City, declaring on Christmas Eve that the deposed dictator's ``reign of terror is over.'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said top Bush administration deputies were meeting into the night at the White House ``considering an appropriate course of action for bringing him to justice.'' U.S. military officers, meanwhile, hoped Noriega's action would ``take the spirit to resist'' out of loyalists still fighting in Panama, said a Pentagon spokesman, Col. Miguel Monteverde. He said it was not clear whether the development would hasten the withdrawal of U.S. troops. Under international law, diplomatic missions are safe havens for those seeking asylum and Noriega is not the only prominent figure to take advantage of this convention. Since June, Chinese dissident Fang Lizhi has kept Chinese authorities at bay by taking refuge in the U.S. Embassy in Beijing. While Fitzwater said the administration wants to bring Noriega to justice, he declined to say whether that would involve a U.S. effort to gain custody of the general, who is under indictment in the United States on drug trafficking charges. Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., said White House chief of staff John Sununu told him ``strenuous negotiations'' with the Vatican were ongoing. U.S. officials are ``pointing out that (Noriega) is not there for political reasons, he is, as Sununu told me, a common criminal,'' Helms told The Associated Press. ``I asked him if the prospects look good and he says they don't look bad, because the church realizes how the people feel in Panama,'' Helms said. Helms said ``sources in Panama say that he (Noriega) probably went in with the escort of a diplomat. He is seeking to be permitted to leave and go to one of two or three counties, including Cuba.'' Earlier, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney had said it was uncertain whether the United States would seek to try Noriega or whether the new government in Panama would deal with him. The Italian news agency ANSA quoted the papal nuncio in Panama City, Monsignor Sebastiano Laboa, as indicating he would not hand over Noriega to the United States or the U.S.-installed government in Panama. Noriega's lawyer in Miami, Raymond Takiff, said Sunday that Noriega's action surprised him: ``I was sure he'd die in Panama.'' U.S. inability to capture Noriega had become a sore point for the administration, which earlier Sunday fended off criticism that civil order in Panama was being undermined by his continued freedom. Bush was at the presidential retreat at Camp David when he got word Sunday afternoon of Noriega's request for asylum at the Vatican mission. In Washington, press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said on behalf of Bush: ``We have been notified by the papal nuncio in Panama City that General Noriega has turned himself in at their embassy.'' ``I am pleased that the general is now under the control of diplomatic authorities. His reign of terror is over,'' said the statement. ``As we work to help return law and order to Panama City, and as the government of President (Guillermo) Endara begins its work, the demise of General Noriega sends a strong signal that freedom and democracy in Panama are on the rise.'' Earlier Sunday, Bush had traveled to the Pentagon for a briefing on Panama developments, and he dispatched Defense Secretary Dick Cheney to Panama City just hours before Noriega's asylum bid was disclosed. Archbishop Marcos McGrath of Panama City, asked by CBS-TV why Noriega went to the Vatican mission, said, ``Apparently he decided that the moment had come to end his resistance. And he made contacts by telephone and drove in a private car and walked into the Papal Nuncio's residence and thereby entered into an area of diplomatic immunity.'' ``Apparently he went in alone and he would be out of the area of arrest either by the Panamanian government authorities or any action of the U.S. military,'' the Roman Catholic archbishop said. Under diplomatic tradition, Noriega is safe from arrest as long as he remains inside the diplomatic mission, or until agreement is reached on terms for him to leave the area of immunity. At the State Department's Panama Task Force, Richard Sanders said administration officials had not decided whether to take steps to bring Noriega to the United States. Putting Noriega on trial poses risks to the United States. Noriega formerly had an association with the Central Intelligence Agency and might be in a position to disclose embarrassing details of that relationship. In defending himself for trial, he could seek to use classified documents in his defense. U.S. military officials had anticipated that Noriega might seek diplomatic sanctuary, and on Thursday troops were sent to ring the Panama City embassies of Nicaragua and Cuba. Top administration officials discussed the Panama invasion on television interview shows Sunday, acknowledging that the 24,000 U.S. soldiers now there ``still have a lot of work to do'' to restore order. Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Cheney defended the administration against criticism it had not acted quickly enough to quell looting in Panama City after U.S. troops invaded early Wednesday. U.S. forces initially concentrated on military targets, but are now working more with Endara's government to restore order, Cheney said on ABC's ``This Week with David Brinkley.'' ``The looting is dying out,'' said Cheney. He acknowledged that some pro-Noriega paramilitary forces, known as ``Dignity Battalions,'' were ``running loose in the streets, but the situation appears to be steadily improving.'' ``It's not all over yet,'' he said. ``We still have a lot of work to do, but clearly we are in better shape today than at any point since the effort started.'' In a broadcast to U.S. Armed Forces around the world, Bush said America ``has the strength to confront tyranny when we must. Gen. Noriega is the latest to learn that lesson.'' Bush told reporters outside the Pentagon that ``the emphasis now is on cleaning up the last parts of resistance, seeing that civilian government take over, (restoring) tranquility in the city and then moving on food and medicine.'' Baker, appearing on the NBC-TV program ``Meet the Press,'' reiterated the administration position that the U.S. troops will remain in Panama ``as long as it takes to get the job done.'' The Pentagon's casualty figures stood at 24 U.S. servicemen killed in action, 284 wounded, and two civilian dependents killed. Earlier, Pentagon officials had said 25 U.S. servicemen died, but later reported that they had been counting one death twice. Casualties for the Panamanian Defense Forces were 154 killed, 113 wounded and 2,969 captured, the Pentagon reported. Additionally, about 18,000 weapons had been captured. Official tallies of Panamanian civilian casualties were unavailable, but the Air Force said a C-5 cargo plane loaded with medical supplies was sent from South Carolina to help treat injured civilians.
